content:
Does there exist a repository of mappings from English paragraphs with LaTeX to "how you'd declare that in Lean"? Say I wanted to make an AI that could convert informal English-math into Lean statements. What is the closest related project to this, that you know of?

For example "Let $G$ be a group." would convert to a code listing that does all the necessary imports at the start, and defines a symbol - should just be ascii G itself - to be of type group. But it's not simply just converting each paragraph and concatenating the results, there's probably a lot of orchestrating that needs to be done so that the end Lean code is valid.

• https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.06502
  • https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.02636
  • https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-53518-6_1
  • http://aitp-conference.org/2020/abstract/paper_33.pdf
  • Some of these also have videos of their talks at AITP: http://aitp-conference.org/

It is a very hard problem.
I almost forgot the best result: #general > Introducing GPT-AF (announced April 1 of this year)

What if you first converted all Lean code (all code that can be webscraped) into English, since generating a language is way easier than parsing one, that would give you a corpus of mappings. As far as all the permutations of the English-math equivalent in meaning, that would be handled with NLP.
@Jason Rute that was funny :) But, surely, what a fertile area of research it is.
I perused the NMT engines (FOSS) and found this canonical C++ one: https://marian-nmt.github.io/
Daniel Donnelly has marked this topic as resolved.
Wow! "Converting informal math language to Lean" has been resolved :rofl: Time to retire.
